question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute
\[
\begin{vmatrix} \cos 1 & \cos 2 & \cos 3 \\ \cos 4 & \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix}
.\]All the angles are in radians.
inference:
Let $A = \begin{vmatrix} \cos 1 & \cos 2 & \cos 3 \\ \cos 4 & \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix}$.

Using the property of determinant, we can expand along the first row:
\begin{align*} A &= \cos 1 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} - \cos 2 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} + \cos 3 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 5 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 \end{vmatrix} \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos 5 \cos 9 - \cos 6 \cos 8) - \cos 2 (\cos 4 \cos 9 - \cos 6 \cos 7) + \cos 3 (\cos 4 \cos 8 - \cos 5 \cos 7) \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos (5-9)) - \cos 2 (\cos (4-9)) + \cos 3 (\cos (4-8)) + \cos 1 (\cos (5+9)) - \cos 2 (\cos (4+9)) + \cos 3 (\cos (4+8)) \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos (-4)) - \cos 2 (\cos (-5)) + \cos 3 (\cos (-4)) + \cos 1 (\cos (14)) - \cos 2 (\cos (13)) + \cos 3 (\cos (12)) \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos (4)) - \cos 2 (\cos (5)) + \cos 3 (\cos (4)) + \cos 1 (\cos (14)) - \cos 2 (\cos (13)) + \cos 3 (\cos (12)) \\ &= 2 \cos 1 \cos 4 + 2 \cos 3 \cos 4 - 2 \cos 2 \cos 5 \end{align*}
By using the property
\[ 2\cos a\cos b = \cos(a+b) + \cos(a-b)\]
\begin{align*}
A &= \cos 1 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} - \cos 2 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} + \cos 3 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 5 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= \cos 1 (\cos 45 - \cos 14) - \cos 2 (\cos 36 - \cos 13) + \cos 3 (\cos 32 - \cos 12) \\
&= \cos(1) \cos(4) - \cos(2) \cos(5) + \cos(3) \cos(4) \end{align*}
Notice that the cosine functions in the determinant have integer multiples of $\pi/3$.

The determinant is 0.

Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$
ground_truth:
The entries in each row are $\cos n,$ $\cos (n + 1),$ and $\cos (n + 2)$ for some integer $n.$  From the angle addition formula,
\[\cos n + \cos (n + 2) = 2 \cos (n + 1) \cos 1.\]Then
\[\cos (n + 2) = 2 \cos 1 \cos (n + 1) - \cos n.\]Thus, we can obtain the third column of the matrix by multiplying the second column by $2 \cos 1,$ and subtracting the first column.  In other words, the third column is a linear combination of the first two columns.  Therefore, the determinant is $\boxed{0}.$

question:
Let $A = \begin{vmatrix} \cos 1 & \cos 2 & \cos 3 \\ \cos 4 & \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix}$.

Using the property of determinant, we can expand along the first row:
\begin{align*} A &= \cos 1 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} - \cos 2 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} + \cos 3 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 5 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 \end{vmatrix} \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos 5 \cos 9 - \cos 6 \cos 8) - \cos 2 (\cos 4 \cos 9 - \cos 6 \cos 7) + \cos 3 (\cos 4 \cos 8 - \cos 5 \cos 7) \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos (5-9)) - \cos 2 (\cos (4-9)) + \cos 3 (\cos (4-8)) + \cos 1 (\cos (5+9)) - \cos 2 (\cos (4+9)) + \cos 3 (\cos (4+8)) \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos (-4)) - \cos 2 (\cos (-5)) + \cos 3 (\cos (-4)) + \cos 1 (\cos (14)) - \cos 2 (\cos (13)) + \cos 3 (\cos (12)) \\ &= \cos 1 (\cos (4)) - \cos 2 (\cos (5)) + \cos 3 (\cos (4)) + \cos 1 (\cos (14)) - \cos 2 (\cos (13)) + \cos 3 (\cos (12)) \\ &= 2 \cos 1 \cos 4 + 2 \cos 3 \cos 4 - 2 \cos 2 \cos 5 \end{align*}
By using the property
\[ 2\cos a\cos b = \cos(a+b) + \cos(a-b)\]
\begin{align*}
A &= \cos 1 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 5 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 8 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} - \cos 2 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 6 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 9 \end{vmatrix} + \cos 3 \begin{vmatrix} \cos 4 & \cos 5 \\ \cos 7 & \cos 8 \end{vmatrix} \\
&= \cos 1 (\cos 45 - \cos 14) - \cos 2 (\cos 36 - \cos 13) + \cos 3 (\cos 32 - \cos 12) \\
&= \cos(1) \cos(4) - \cos(2) \cos(5) + \cos(3) \cos(4) \end{align*}
Notice that the cosine functions in the determinant have integer multiples of $\pi/3$.

The determinant is 0.

Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
ground_truth:
The entries in each row are $\cos n,$ $\cos (n + 1),$ and $\cos (n + 2)$ for some integer $n.$  From the angle addition formula,
\[\cos n + \cos (n + 2) = 2 \cos (n + 1) \cos 1.\]Then
\[\cos (n + 2) = 2 \cos 1 \cos (n + 1) - \cos n.\]Thus, we can obtain the third column of the matrix by multiplying the second column by $2 \cos 1,$ and subtracting the first column.  In other words, the third column is a linear combination of the first two columns.  Therefore, the determinant is $\boxed{0}.$
